title: Return to the office beckons
text:
This article is an on-site version of our Coronavirus Business Update newsletter. Please share this with friends and colleagues who might find it valuable and let them know that, even if they are not subscribers to the Financial Times, they can read the newsletter — and all of the FT — free for 30 days. Welcome and please sign up here.

Get the latest worldwide picture with our vaccine tracker

Latest news

  • The World Economic Forum has again been forced to cancel plans for an in-person annual meeting this year in Singapore as infections in the city-state rise

  • Turkey eased pandemic restrictions after an 18-day lockdown led to a drop in new infections

  • Developers said a new antiviral drug had almost wiped out coronavirus in mice and could be suitable for humans

For up-to-the-minute coronavirus updates, visit our live blog

Albeit with a “heavy dose of caution” from the prime minister and warnings from scientists, the next stage of unlocking finally got under way across the UK today. Pubs, cafés and restaurants in England were allowed to serve customers indoors, limited foreign travel was legalised and cultural venues and sports stadiums could lift their shutters, moves mirrored in some of the EU's biggest countries.

The reopenings mean many staff in the hospitality sector are now back in their workplaces, but for office employees the great return is still in its early stages, with companies divided over how to reorganise their workforces in light of the changes wrought by the pandemic.

In financial services, views differ on either side of the Atlantic. JPMorgan chief Jamie Dimon wants American bankers back at their desks as soon as possible while Société Générale boss Frédéric Oudéa has dismissed as outdated “the idea that winning is just about spending 22 hours during the day at the office”. Others, such as accountancy firm BDO, say they are happy to let staff work wherever they want. 

But what happens if “hybrid” workers only want to come in Tuesdays to Thursdays? Do companies need to hire celebrity chefs to tempt them back on Mondays and Fridays? And what is the effect of homeworking on productivity?

Whether workers will even have the choice of commuting to an office is also moot. Our Big Read takes stock of the commercial property market, with many buildings lying empty and big employers having outlined intentions to shrink their requirements for floor space. 

As columnist Emma Jacobs writes today, the shift to working from home also risks creating a two-tier workforce, with fewer development opportunities for those working remotely to network with colleagues, especially women with caring responsibilities.  

The onus is on management to prevent the forming of new cliques that foster discrimination, she says. Or as one academic explains: “We may not have tonnes of data on the disparate impact of hybrid policies on underprivileged groups, but it is naive to assume it won't happen. The big question is how to mitigate it.”

Global economy

The EU is pushing to expand vaccine manufacturing in Africa, a move the bloc believes will be more beneficial for poorer nations than the drug patent waivers proposed by the US. Ayoade Alakija, co-chair of the Africa Vaccine Delivery Alliance, writes in the FT on the need for the continent to become self-sufficient in diagnostics, therapeutics and vaccine production. “No one will help us if we do not attempt to help ourselves. It is time to stop feeding off the scraps from the table of high-income countries,” she says.

Increasing unrest in Colombia over government remedies for a pandemic-induced recession and one of the world's longest lockdowns could spill over into the rest of the region, writes Latin America editor Michael Stott. In Brazil, a power struggle between President Jair Bolsonaro and the Supreme Court over pandemic policy is deepening.

Tea harvests at plantations in India, the world's second-largest tea producer after China, are under threat from the double hit of Covid infections and drought. A leading Indian scientist has quit the government's task force as rows have deepened over Prime Minister Narendra Modi's handling of the pandemic, which, according to official figures, has led to more than 40,000 cases and more than 4,000 deaths a day.

Business

JD Logistics, the delivery arm of Chinese ecommerce group JD.com, is looking to raise up to £$3.4bn in what could be one of Hong Kong's largest initial public offerings this year and the latest sign of the rise of online shopping. Indonesia's two biggest start-ups are merging to create ecommerce group GoTo, with a potential stock market value of $40bn. Our future of retail series continues with a look at how the pandemic is driving ecommerce forward in Japan after a slow start.

Ryanair, Europe's biggest low-cost airline, reported its biggest annual loss of €815m after enduring an 80 per cent drop in passengers during the pandemic, a crisis also discussed in our latest “How to Lead” interview featuring Dublin Airport boss Dalton Philips. The EU could this week allow member states to follow Portugal — one of the countries most dependent on tourism, which accounts for 17 per cent national output and 19 per cent of jobs — and allow entry to UK visitors. Greece is leading the way on mechanisms for safe travel ahead of the EU's digital “green certificate”, reports our Europe Express newsletter.

Drugmaker GlaxoSmithKline signalled it was back in the vaccine race after publishing promising trial results with partner Sanofi. The company, which has been under investor pressure to beef up its drugs pipeline, is talking to governments about new manufacturing facilities and investing heavily in messenger RNA, the technology behind the successful vaccines from BioNTech/Pfizer and Moderna.

Markets

The plunge in government bond yields caused by the pandemic is leading central banks to hunt out new riskier assets, including corporate bonds, emerging market bonds and equities. Managers of foreign currency reserves are typically highly risk-averse but with more than $12tn in cash to play with, they have huge influence on markets.

Panic over inflation is just the latest sign of investor overreaction, writes US financial editor Robert Armstrong in the first edition of Unhedged, our new markets newsletter. “Get used to weeks like last week. It's gonna be a weird couple of years,” he writes. What better time to sign up and get Unhedged in your inbox each weekday morning?

Interest in gold as a haven asset is growing again as investors get spooked by the growth in Covid cases in Asia and the Caribbean and the new panic over inflation, leading to last week becoming the worst for global stocks since late February.

Have your say

H. Ickx comments on How mRNA became a vaccine game-changer:

Real human progress cannot be achieved by short-term capitalist markers solely. It has required loads of public money and, especially, patience to eventually get the result we see now. A healthy tax on private profits is only just and desirable, as all private profits rely on the past and present efforts of the entire society. Also mind, worldwide there are now many scientists doing research that might not show any concrete result any time soon, maybe never. Or maybe their work will be picked up only decades from now. They are not losers — their work is all fundamental to our progress.

Final thought
